RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter©, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter© as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter©.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter© to create, schedule, track, and document events, Del Monte Fresh Produce has also entered into a contract with California Controlled Atmosphere to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation. A copy of California Controlled Atmosphere's service agreement has been included in this program with the support material.

For the future, Del Monte Fresh Produce now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Del Monte Fresh Produce employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Del Monte Fresh Produce will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.

1	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

¿	California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
¿	Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
¿	California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
¿	Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Del Monte Fresh Produce has elected to use PSMWriter©, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1	DEL MONTE FRESH PRODUCE, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Del Monte Fresh Produce has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Ammonia	Refrigeration | 32,200 lb

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.

Del Monte Fresh Produce has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1.	Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet Cal

ARP and RMP obligations as well
2.	Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Del Monte Fresh Produce business practices
3.	Utilized PSMWriter© software to ensure that all necessary Del Monte Fresh Produce employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.

1.2	PROCESS DESCRIPTION

Del Monte operates a food processing facility and cold storage for fresh produce.  Our facility has one ammonia system which provides refrigerating capacity to two processing rooms, multiple cold storage and controlled atmosphere storage rooms, a hallway and a loading dock area.  There is also a hydrocooler on sight which is to be disconnected from the system as it is no longer in use.

The systems operate as follows.  High pressure liquid from our main receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature & pressure accumulator vessels.  From the accumulators, cold liquid ammonia is circulated through evaporator coils.  As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia evaporates to form low temperature & pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessel.  The ammonia vapor is returned from the accumulator vessels through a suction return line to our main suction accumulator in the engine room. From there the gas is piped to the compressors.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to our receiver.

The facility was originally built in 1979 by professional refrigeration engineers in accordance with standard design, and installation of ammonia mechanical refrigerating systems.  It was also built in compliance with the Uniform Mechanical Code and Uniform Building Code applicable at the time of construction. The system contains numerous safety devices

including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.  Lastly, an emergency dump box contains valves to vent ammonia if necessary.

The ammonia system at our facility consists of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected. 

Therefore, we are treating our system as a single process. 

1.3	GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

1.3.1	GENERAL 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Del Monte Fresh Produce has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program. 

1.3.2	ANHYDROUS AMMONIA

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Del Monte Fresh Produce facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanic

al integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4	FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Del Monte Fresh has had one (1) accident within the last five (5) years.

Incident Investigation # 2016-­02
Date of incident: December 15, 2016
Time accident began: 5:47 PM
NAICS: 115114
Accident duration: 16 hours
Regulated substance released: Anhydrous Ammonia
Estimated quantity released: 24,000 lbs.
Release event: Gas release & Liquid spills/evaporation
Source: Anhydrous Ammonia release through broken piping
Weather conditions: Wind speed and direction: 9.2 mph SSE
Temperature: 55 degrees F 
Atmospheric stability class: D
Precipitation present: Raining
Onsite impacts: Property Damage, no injuries or deaths
Offsite impacts: Sheltered in place (total unknown), no injuries or deaths

Initiating event and contributing factors:

During a heavy rainstorm, the roof over the Finish Product Room collapsed. Two (2) ceiling­-suspended evaporative coils fell with the roof, breaking the piping between the roof mounted accumulator and the two (2) coils. Upon inspection, the wooden roof supports displayed water damage which led to rot and weakened the beams.
Offsite responders notified and responded

Recommendations:

The ceiling­-suspending evaporative coils, accumulator and piping was severely damaged during the 12/15/16 roof collapse. Ensure to isolate, safely remove and repair process equipment in accordance with IIAR standards. Additionally, ensure that Management of Change/Pre-­Startup Safety Review documentation is completed in accordance with RMP/PSM/CalARP regulations.

Ensure to have a structural engineer evaluate the entire roof to determine if structurally sound and safe to re­occupy facility. Repair all sections of roof and supporting structure which are inadequate.

Del Monte Fresh employees evacuated in a safe and timely manner, with no reportable injuries. However, Del Monte management could not provide relevant site maps and piping and instrument

ation diagrams to emergency responders. Maps and P&IDs were brought onsite by consultants nearly four hours after the roof collapse. Complete emergency response training with designated Del Monte Fresh employees. Ensure to emphasize assessing emergency situations, notifications and contractor support.

1.5	EMERGENCY ACTION AND RESPONSE PLAN

Del Monte Fresh Produce's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

¿	California Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
¿	Federal Emergency Action Plan - Title 29 CFR §1910.38 
¿	California Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 §5192(q)
¿	Federal Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR §1910.120(q)

Strategically, we will respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Our company has an outstanding safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Many policies and procedures have been implemented to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Del Monte Fresh Produce continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter© software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Del Monte Fresh Produce's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter© tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Del Monte Fresh Produce's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.
